title: April 16
description:
We hiked, surfed, snorkeled, rafted and zip-lined through the beautiful country of Costa Rica for two weeks.

Along the way we collected our fair share of bug bites, scrapes, sunburns and jellyfish stings. We saw lots of wildlife including sloths, iguanas and poison dart frogs.

Felix got his hair pulled by a monkey and a bloody nose from a surfboard, Milo got his ankles pulled by two monkey tails in a coordinated attack, and Dean stepped on a stingray. Other adventures include crossing a very long rope bridge in epic rain, getting lost in the snake-infested jungle at night, jumping off a waterfall and spending a few nights in a treehouse.

We're having a hard time adjusting back to the real world.

children.title: Manuel Antonio
children.description:
Bright and early our first morning in Costa Rica, we donned our explorer vests and hiked Manuel Antonio National Park in search of wildlife.

We quickly spotted a large troop of squirrel monkeys jumping branch to branch.

We also saw several impish raccoons, a couple of lazy sloths high up in the trees, monkeys chilling on the beach and a giant rodent called an agouti.

children.title: There!
children.description: This is a family of capuchin monkeys.

children.title: Capuchin
children.description: White-face capuchin monkeys, chilling and grooming.

children.title: La Posada
children.description:
We spent our first two nights in Costa Rica at the hotel La Posada, steps away from the entrance of Manuel Antonio.

The weather and hot and humid. The pool was very much appreciated.

children.title: Money
children.description:
Costa Rica has the best looking money ever. We want whoever designed those bills to work on the American dollar next!

Don't you think dollars would look so much better with colorful images of eagles, bears and other American wildlife?

children.title: Snow Cones
children.description:
Ticos (i.e. Costa Ricans) must not have much of a sweet tooth. Restaurants rarely offer desserts and we saw no ice cream stands or other sweets peddlers. Ticos seem content eating lots of fresh fruit -- wisely so!

Sole exception: snow cone carts on the beach. The shaved ice gets layered with fruit-flavored syrup and powdered milk. Sweet condensed milk is drizzled on top.

children.title: Beach
children.description: The beach in Quepos.
Felix's height is to Lucie's what Lucie's is to Dean's, if that makes any sense. Five inches and shrinking.

children.title: Sunset
children.description: Costa Rica is six degrees from the equator.  The sun falls out of the sky like  it was dropped.  Night descends promptly and abruptly at 5:30 pm.

children.title: El Avion
children.description:
This restaurant is built around a C-123 cargo plane involved in the Iran-Contra affair, one of the biggest political scandals of the 1980s.

This plane was used by the US government to illegally ship weapons to rebels in Nicaragua.

children.title: Contra Bar
children.description:
On October 5, 1986, the twin sister of this plane was shot down over Nicaragua.

A crew member, CIA operative Eugene Hasenfus, parachuted to safety and was captured by the Sandinista army.

Led out of the jungle at gun point, Hasenfusâ€™s existence set in motion an incredible chain of cover-ups and lies that would mushroom into one of the biggest political scandals of the 1980's.

children.title: Costa Paraiso
children.description: Next stop: a little resort near the tiny beach town of Dominical.

children.title: Batidos
children.description:
We drank A LOT of smoothies ("batidos") made with fresh tropical fruit.

In general we loved Costa Rican food: fresh, healthy, delicious!

We worked a lot on the kids' restaurant spanish. They got pretty good at ordering batidos, fajitas and other Costa Rican delicacies.

children.title: Iguana
children.description:
Iguanas roamed Costa Paraiso's garden. They plucked the mangoes right out of the tree.

Another common reptile in Costa Rica is the Jesus Lizard, so named because it can run across water.

children.title: Waves
children.description: Playing in the surf:  still a family favorite.

children.title: Evening
children.description:
The middle of the day got pretty beastly hot and wasn't good for hanging out at the beach.

But as late afternoon arrived, the northern European albinos ventured forth to play in the sand.

children.title: Kid Wash
children.description: Felix enjoys a reflective moment in the gentle surf.

children.title: Surf Camp
children.description: The next day we reported for duty at Surf Camp.

children.title: Milo
children.description:
Milo's spent years honing his California surfer boy image.

Now, the moment of truth: can he put his feet where his flowing blond tresses already are?

children.title: Felix
children.description: Felix had more cred than Milo getting to the water:  at least he could carry his board unassisted all the way.

children.title: First Up
children.description:
We had two fabulous instructors and it turned out the whole family was able to catch some waves!

Dean was by far the best by virtue of having surfed a bit, pre-kids.

Felix managed to give himself a massive bloody nose during a wipeout, but impressively soldiered on.

Milo surfed until he literally dropped from exhaustion and had to be dragged up the beach.

children.title: Riptides
children.description:
The next day we rented boards and went surfing by ourselves.

The conditions were MUCH tougher, but we all got some waves.

It was only as we left that we saw how much tougher the conditions were.

children.title: Rafiki Safari Lodge
children.description:
Next stop: Rafiki Safari Lodge, a safari camp nestled in a river valley at the end of a 16km dirt road. Four wheel drive recommended.

We lived in a safari tent overlooking a pond containing at least one resident caiman (a type of crocodile).

children.title: Dean
children.description: Rafiki is run by a very friendly south african family .  They transplanted the safari esthetic to central america and it works pretty well.

children.title: Dean and Milo
children.description: I'm not sure real African safari camps have hot tubs like this.

children.title: Lucie and the Kids
children.description: Hi from Costa Rica!

children.title: Water Slide
children.description:
Felix and Milo really appreciated Rafiki's high speed water slide.

It was fast enough to cause a few scrapes and bruises. Fun!

children.title: Pineapples
children.description: Did you know that a pineapple plant is a small shrub and that it only bears one fruit every two years?

children.title: Hike
children.description:
Taking a hike in the area around Rafiki.

There are a few tiny villages around, where nobody has a car. The bridges are people-sized instead of car-sized.

children.title: Lucie
children.description:
To be classified as a village in Costa Rica, you need three things: a school, a church and a soccer field.

You don't need: cars, street signs, a stop light, or a store.

children.title: Suspension Bridge
children.description:
As we hiked across this extremely long suspension bridge, the heavens opened and we were caught in a torrential downpour.

There was so much rain we felt like we were walking through the inside of a waterfall!

Turns out we experienced the first rain of the rainy season. It hadn't rained up to this point, and from this point on, it rained every day.

children.title: Belly Flop
children.description:
Our guide for the hike, one of the brothers who owns Rafiki, did a perfect flip into this pool.

Milo tried to imitate, here, and ended up doing the highest belly flop we've ever seen.

He was obviously hurting afterwards, but he didn't cry, and he kept jumping -- though now with feet pointed firmly downwards. Stoic kid!

children.title: Waterfall Felix
children.description: We kept firmly sun-protected.

children.title: Dean
children.description: Even with all the sun precautions, we all got some sunburns this trip.

children.title: Snogging
children.description: Snogging in a stream.

children.title: Lucie and Milo
children.description: Hugging in a water hole.

children.title: Family Waterfall
children.description: Dean tries a new method of protecting himself from the cascade.

children.title: Family
children.description: Warning: you might get to see this shot again on our Christmas card later this year.

children.title: Rafting
children.description:
The next day: a rafting adventure down the mighty Savegre river!

Savegre = "savage"

children.title: Parent Raft
children.description:
Dean and Lucie were together in a raft with an excellent guide who fished using a spool of line every chance he got.

He hooked a couple, but they got off his line before he could get them into the raft.

He was kind enough not to fish while our lives were on the line in the rapids.

children.title: Smiles
children.description: It was pretty exciting, but none of the rafts flipped.

children.title: Kid Raft
children.description: The kids had made some friends at Rafiki and went down the river with them.

children.title: Friends
children.description: The kids' friends were from Los Altos, about 40 miles from Berkeley in the bay area.

children.title: Action!
children.description: Splash!

children.title: Paddles Up!
children.description: Everybody agreed:  we're going rafting again!

children.title: Plantation
children.description:
We drove through many fields of palm trees before realizing that we were surrounded by palm oil plantations.

Costa Rica's main crop used to be coffee. Then it became bananas. Costa Rica is also a big exporter of cacao, pineapple and other exotic fruits. Palm oil is the latest trend.

At first, Milo was appalled. Palm oil is his arch enemy. However, he soften a bit when he learned that Costa Rica has strict laws prohibiting any rainforest tree from being cut. The new palm oil plantations can only be planted on existing farm land.

children.title: Palm Oil
children.description: Palm kernels grow in densely-packed bunches. The bunches are harvested when they turn orange. The kernels are pressed to make palm oil.

children.title: Silencio
children.description:
Next stop: Silencio Wildlife Rescue Center.

It's also in the middle of the same nowhere as Rafiki. It rescues monkeys, raccoons, owls and other local animals.

children.title: Monkey Petting
children.description:
Two Belgian teenagers met us. They had been there a week on some sort of government work program and knew next to nothing about how to run a wildlife center. There didn't seem to be any adults around.

But they were doing their best, and had made friends with the monkeys.

This spider monkey is Alejandro. He used to work in a bar, amusing the patrons by smoking and drinking with them. Someone alerted the rescue center and Alejandro was taken away from the bar.

children.title: Stranger Danger
children.description: Some of the monkeys had been abused pets and really didn't like humans.

children.title: Meeting of the Minds
children.description:
Milo the primatologist was in heaven: he talked knowledgeably about the monkeys and their habits.

Coca the capuchin monkey shook Milo's hands.

children.title: Raccoon
children.description: The Belgian teens let a raccoon out of her cage, who followed us around like a dog.

children.title: On The Loose
children.description:
McGee the spider monkey had been released to the wild the previous week, but he kept hanging around with the caged monkeys.

In the end, things got a little hairy. McGee caught a handful of Felix's hair and refused to let go. It was a hair-raising 15 seconds. Though in the end, no damage done.

Then, two monkeys stuck their tails out of their cage and wrapped them around Milo's ankles, pulling him towards the cage. Milo managed to break free, but it was clear: the humans weren't fully in charge at this wildlife center.

Excitement!

children.title: Crocodiles
children.description: Back on the main road, we passed over a bridge with a bunch of crocodiles.  Just, you know, hanging out.

children.title: Finca Bellavista
children.description: Next stop:  Finca Bellavista, a kinda granola-crunchy community of mostly Americans living in treehouses in the jungle.

children.title: The Path
children.description:
The path to our treehouse was a 20 minute hike through the jungle, crossing this river on a suspension bridge.

The rubber boots are to ward off snakes.

children.title: Treehouse
children.description: Our treehouse!

children.title: Mis Ojos
children.description: It's name is Mis Ojos which means My Eyes.

children.title: Breakfast Nook
children.description: Our breakfast nook.

children.title: Arch
children.description: The details in the treehouse were fantastic.

children.title: Aerie
children.description: Hanging out 80 feet above the jungle floor.

children.title: Private Waterfall
children.description: Mis Ojos is built in front of a waterfall.

children.title: Swim
children.description: All day and night the roaring of the water filled the air.

children.title: Card Sharks
children.description: Finca Bellavista's base camp.   Meals were taken community-style.

children.title: Basket Weaving
children.description:
The night we arrived they were preparing for a pre-Easter easter egg hunt.

We wove baskets out of palm fronds.

children.title: Easter Egg Painting
children.description: Painting easter eggs.

children.title: Pura Vida
children.description: Pura vida is Costa Rica's national greeting. It means "pure life", but you can use it for hello, goodbye, "yo", or "no worries".

children.title: The Kids
children.description:
The kids with their palm frond baskets.

It is, in fact, Palm Sunday.

children.title: The Hunt
children.description:
The hunt begins!

Kids from the local village were also invited.

children.title: The Loot
children.description: Felix and Milo display their loot.

children.title: Hula
children.description: Milo found a hula hoop.

children.title: Garden Tour
children.description:
Finca Bellavista's head chef took us on a tour of the garden.

Note Dean's spiffy new Finca Bellavista shirt. We did no laundry on this trip and after 10 days of nonstop sweating, the three shirts he bought were stinky beyond belief.

children.title: Boots
children.description:
Finca Bellavista grows most of the fruits and vegetables needed to feed its guests in its organic garden.

We tasted all sort of plants. The kids' favorite were stevia and sugar cane.

children.title: Cooking
children.description: The garden tour included a cooking class. The kids were mostly interested in handling large knifes.

children.title: Colibri
children.description: A colibri flew into our treehouse and stayed trapped there for a while. The same thing happened to a bat.

children.title: Poison Dart Frog
children.description:
There are a lot of frogs in the jungle. At night it was a real cacophony, dominated by the ding frog, which sounds like a metal spoon banging against a cup.

We were lucky to spot two colorful poison dart frogs. One bright green with black dots. The other one red with bright blue legs (pictured).

children.title: Ziplining
children.description: Until the last moment, we weren't sure we would be able to enjoy Finca Bellavista's zip lines. The minimum age was 12. After a couple of days of gentle negotiations, the owner agreed to let Milo try it out as long as the harness fit him. It did, but just barely. Milo is tall for his age, but he is skinny.

children.title: Soaring
children.description: Go Felix!

children.title: Big Grin
children.description: Oops, Milo. Your helmet fell off.

children.title: Suspended
children.description: Lucy in the sky.

children.title: Zipping
children.description: These aren't classified as "professional" zip lines, which allows them to be much closer to trees than per regulation, and have no brake mechanism. We used our gloved hands to slow down.

children.title: Stuck
children.description:
On the longest zip line, Milo got stuck in the middle because he wasn't quite heavy enough to slide the whole way. Our guide had to go and rescue him. As you can tell, Milo did not find the experience distressful in the least.

Epic!

children.title: Thumbs Up
children.description: Thumbs Up for zip lining.

children.title: Bye
children.description: Pura Vida!
